an2.52:1.1: “Two people, mendicants, arise in the world for the welfare and happiness of the people, for the benefit, welfare, and happiness of gods and humans.
an2.52:1.3: The Realized One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha; and the wheel-turning monarch.
an2.52:1.4: These two people arise in the world for the welfare and happiness of the people, for the benefit, welfare, and happiness of gods and humans.”
an2.53:1.1: “Two people, mendicants, arise in the world who are incredible human beings.
an2.53:1.3: The Realized One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha; and the wheel-turning monarch.
an2.53:1.4: These are the two people who arise in the world who are incredible human beings.”
an2.54:1.1: “There are two people, mendicants, whose death is regretted by many people.
an2.54:1.3: The Realized One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha; and the wheel-turning monarch.
an2.54:1.4: These are the two people, mendicants, whose death is regretted by many people.”
an2.55:1.1: “Mendicants, these two are worthy of a monument.
an2.55:1.3: The Realized One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha; and the wheel-turning monarch.
an2.55:1.4: These are the two who are worthy of a monument.”
an2.56:1.1: “Mendicants, there are two kinds of Buddhas.
an2.56:1.3: The Realized One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha; and an independent Buddha.
an2.56:1.4: These are the two kinds of Buddhas.”
an2.57:1.1: “These two, mendicants, are not startled by a crack of thunder.
an2.57:1.3: A mendicant who has ended defilements; and a thoroughbred elephant.
an2.57:1.4: These are the two who are not startled by a crack of thunder.”
an2.58:1.1: “These two, mendicants, are not startled by a crack of thunder.
an2.58:1.3: A mendicant who has ended defilements; and a thoroughbred horse.
an2.58:1.4: These are the two who are not startled by a crack of thunder.”
an2.59:1.1: “These two, mendicants, are not startled by a crack of thunder.
an2.59:1.3: A mendicant who has ended defilements; and a lion, king of beasts.
an2.59:1.4: These are the two who are not startled by a crack of thunder.”
an2.60:1.1: “Fauns see two reasons not to use human speech.
an2.60:1.3: Thinking: ‘May we not lie, and may we not misrepresent others with falsehoods.’
an2.60:1.4: Fauns see two reasons not to use human speech.”
an2.61:1.1: “Mendicants, females die without getting enough of two things.
an2.61:1.4: Females die without getting enough of these two things.”
an2.62:1.1: “Mendicants, I will teach you about living with bad people and living with good people.
an2.62:1.2: Listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”
an2.62:2.1: “What is it like living with bad people? How do bad people live together?
an2.62:2.2: It’s when a senior mendicant thinks:
an2.62:2.3: ‘No mendicant, whether senior, middle, or junior, should admonish me;
an2.62:2.4: and I shouldn’t admonish any mendicant, whether senior, middle, or junior.
an2.62:2.5: If a mendicant—whether senior, middle, or junior—were to admonish me, they wouldn’t be sympathetic, and I’d bother them by saying “No!” And anyway I wouldn’t deal with it even if I saw what I did wrong.’
an2.62:2.7: And a middle or a junior mendicant also thinks:
an2.62:2.8: ‘No mendicant, whether senior, middle, or junior, should admonish me;
an2.62:2.9: and I shouldn’t admonish any mendicant, whether senior, middle, or junior.
an2.62:2.10: If a mendicant—whether senior, middle, or junior—were to admonish me, they wouldn’t be sympathetic, and I’d bother them by saying “No!” And anyway I wouldn’t deal with it even if I saw what I did wrong.’
an2.62:2.12: That’s what it’s like living with bad people; that’s how bad people live together.
an2.62:3.1: What is it like living with good people? How do good people live together?
an2.62:3.2: It’s when a senior mendicant thinks:
an2.62:3.3: ‘Any mendicant, whether senior, middle, or junior, should admonish me;
an2.62:3.4: and I should admonish any mendicant, whether senior, middle, or junior.
an2.62:3.5: If a mendicant—whether senior, middle, or junior—were to admonish me, they’d be sympathetic, so I wouldn’t bother them, but say “Thank you!” And I’d deal with it when I saw what I did wrong.’
an2.62:3.7: And a middle or a junior mendicant also thinks:
an2.62:3.8: ‘Any mendicant, whether senior, middle, or junior, may admonish me;
an2.62:3.9: and I’ll admonish any mendicant, whether senior, middle, or junior.
an2.62:3.10: If a mendicant—whether senior, middle, or junior—were to admonish me, they’d be sympathetic, so I wouldn’t bother them, but say “Thank you!” And I’d deal with it when I saw what I did wrong.’
an2.62:3.12: That’s what it’s like living with good people; that’s how good people live together.”
an2.63:1.1: “In a disciplinary issue, when the tale-bearing on both sides—with contempt for each other’s views, resentful, bitter, and exasperated—is not settled internally, you can expect that this disciplinary issue will be
an2.63:1.2: long, fractious, and troublesome, and the mendicants won’t live comfortably.
an2.63:2.1: In a disciplinary issue, when the tale-bearing on both sides—with contempt for each other’s views, resentful, bitter, and exasperated—is well settled internally, you can expect that this disciplinary issue
an2.63:2.2: won’t lead to lasting acrimony and enmity, and the mendicants will live comfortably.”
